intro: Dithyrea, commonly known as the "blue-eyed grass," is a genus of flowering plants in the family Xanthorrhoeaceae. It is characterized by its small, showy flowers that typically have three petals and three sepals, often in shades of blue or violet. These plants are native to various regions in the Americas, particularly in temperate and subtropical climates. Dithyrea species are often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. They play an important role in pollination, attracting insects like bees and flies with their nectar-rich blooms.
